message_1:
What is the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the combustion of 1 mole of methane gas (CH4) in oxygen gas (O2) at standard conditions (25°C and 1 atm pressure)? Given the balanced chemical equation:
CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2H2O(l)
Use the heat of formation values of each compound to calculate the ΔH of the reaction.
message_2:
To calculate the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the combustion of 1 mole of methane gas (CH4) in oxygen gas (O2) at standard conditions, we can use the heat of formation values for each compound involved in the reaction.

The balanced chemical equation is:
CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2H2O(l)

The heat of formation (ΔHf) values for each compound at standard conditions are as follows:
ΔHf [CH4(g)] = -74.8 kJ/mol
ΔHf [O2(g)] = 0 kJ/mol (since it is an element in its standard state)
ΔHf [CO2(g)] = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔHf [H2O(l)] = -285.8 kJ/mol

Now, we can use the following equation to calculate the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the reaction:
ΔH = Σ ΔHf (products) - Σ ΔHf (reactants)

ΔH = [1(-393.5) + 2(-285.8)] - [1(-74.8) + 2(0)]

ΔH = (-393.5 - 571.6) - (-74.8)

ΔH = -965.1 + 74.8

ΔH = -890.3 kJ/mol

Therefore, the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the combustion of 1 mole of methane gas (CH4) in oxygen gas (O2) at standard conditions is -890.3 kJ/mol.
